issues.title: bg classes?
inverted ceil() and floor() in make-row mixin
issues.body:
I just came across a minor issue while debugging another.

I think ceil() and floor() are inverted in the make-row mixin here.
https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/mixins/_grid.scss#L16

The rounded number will always be negative so the result will actually work the opposite way as it does in the col mixins here:
https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/mixins/_grid-framework.scss#L16

In a nutshell the bug shifts the visible content 1px to the right if the grid-gutter-width is an odd number.

little example (first row broken, second default, third fixed):
https://codepen.io/quarkus/pen/oGydpW?editors=1100

Pretty hard to see as its just one pixel, but its noticable on the left edge of the cols

issues.title: clean up font face rules?
issues.body:
https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_glyphicons.scss looks to still contains several now-questionable formats:

- there are no longer any browsers that support `eot`, as the only browsers that supported `eot` were Microsoft IE4 through IE8, all of which have been finally killed off in January of 2016, with Microsoft only officially supporting IE11 and Edge, and for very special enterprise customers, IE9 on Vista SP2. All of these browsers support `woff`, thus making `eot` obsolete and redundant.
- the `svg` font format was abandoned when it become more than apparent it that it was wildly unsuitable for encoding fonts, to the point where the official SVG specifically *removed* the chapter on font-related markup, marking it as out-of-spec markup. SVG-compliant browsers have since removed support for it (because it's no longer part of the spec) and the only browser that still officially supports `svg` fonts also supports `woff`, making `svg` also both obsolete and redundant.
- the `ttf` and `otf` formats, as full-table, uncompressed system fonts, are also not necessary: browsers that support these formats also support `woff`, and should always prefer to load the `woff` resource if one is available. The only exception could be said to be Android 2.x through 4.2.x, but these versions have terrible web font support even when using `ttf` and are on the same level of "you're on your own" when it comes to webfonts as we used to be when we tried to make modern CSS work on IE6, 7, and 8. `ttf` and `otf` also don't enjoy the benefit of compression that `woff` comes with.

So for modern bootstrap, really the only formats needed are `woff` and `woff2`, with the latter of course being preferred because it has better compression for faster delivery over the wire.

issues.title: Breadcrumb variable interpolation breaking sourcemaps
issues.body:
For reference - https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/issues/919

I think the above issue has to be reopened. Sorry if I should be posting there, kinda new to github and its issue/bug tracking.

So from what I can tell, there used to be an issue with how libsass compiled the following:

```
content: "#{$breadcrumb-separator}\00a0";
```

So it got changed to:

```
$nbsp: "\00a0";
content: "#{$breadcrumb-separator}#{$nbsp}";
```

But now that leads to it getting compiled to:

```
content: "/ ";
```

And on top of that if the libsass output style is set to `compressed` it causes source maps to be inaccurate. The other output styles are fine though. I submitted an issue over there - https://github.com/sass/libsass/issues/2319

# Proposition

Because this whole variable interpolation stuff is pretty unreliable and inconsistent across recent versions of libsass, I propose to just hardcode the value. So...

```
content: "/\00a0";
```

That way it will work for people using slightly older versions of libsass and also for people using the recent version(s). And though we won't have a simple variable to change/override, it's super easy to override the old fashion way. For example

```
.breadcrumb>li+li:before {
    content: "\003e\00a0"; // for a ">" instead of a "/"
}
```

I'd much rather have minified css and source maps than a variable for breadcrumbs. I know, as a work around, I could use a separate css minifier, but they add nearly one second to compile time. Libsass is fast and hard to beat and I really like to keep things simple and fast whenever possible.

Thoughts on this?

issues.title: Unnecesary files included in npm package
issues.body:
I noticed that the npm package includes some files that cannot be helpful to consumers. The test directory is included with some transient files - the rails tmp dir and log dir for example. 

Test against the package version we are using:
`curl -s  https://registry.npmjs.org/bootstrap-sass/-/bootstrap-sass-3.3.6.tgz | tar ztv | grep -c dummy_rails/tmp`

> 291

Example: 
`curl -s  https://registry.npmjs.org/bootstrap-sass/-/bootstrap-sass-3.3.6.tgz | tar ztv | grep dummy_rails/tmp`

> `-rw-rw-r-- 1000/1000       198 2015-09-27 07:50 package/test/dummy_rails/tmp/cache/sprockets/v4.0/Vygbc35Z0fLTFlt6RrFwpQyO45HqPALfeo4lCR1vX7o.cache
> ...`

I realize this is not adversely affecting anyone but I think if the solution is clean then the reduced size will be worth it (uncompressed the tmp/cache dir was 1.7M). I don't have experience setting up npm builds but if someone can point me in the right direction I'm happy to get a PR going to tackle this low-hanging fruit.

issues.title: eyeglass import is not consistent with rails/bower/node/etc
issues.body:
In [#1007](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/pull/1007), Eyeglass support was added. This was a great improvement for us as it allowed us to pull more dependencies in through npm.

We have a sass library that works both in Rails's asset pipeline and in other ecosystems. The eyeglass import having a different name in Eyeglass unfortunately makes us choose between only supporting building through eyeglass, or not having eyeglass support and having everything else work.

For example, in Rails:

``` scss
@import "bootstrap";
```

But in eyeglass:

``` scss
@import "bootstrap-sass/bootstrap";
```

If you look at the README in its current state you can see how consistent it is until you get down to the Eyeglass section.

This could be fixed by adding a `name` field to the `eyeglass` section package.json for `bootstrap-sass`:

``` json
{
  "name": "bootstrap-sass",
  "version": "1.1.0",
  "eyeglass": {
    "name": "bootstrap",
    "needs": "^0.6.7",
    "exports": "eyeglass-exports.js"
  }
```

For consistency, I think it would be great if you could `@import "bootstrap"` in any ecosystem and have it work.

This would be a breaking change for anybody currently using eyeglass, but an easy fix to implement (change your import statements to "@import bootstrap").

issues.title: Sass @import "bootstrap-compass" + @import "bootstrap" issue using Compass.
issues.body:
I've created a new project using `compass create <my-project-name> -r bootstrap-sass --using bootstrap` and when I open styles.scss I see the following code: 

```
// Import Bootstrap Compass integration
@import "bootstrap-compass";

// Import custom Bootstrap variables
@import "bootstrap-variables";

// Import Bootstrap for Sass
@import "bootstrap";
```

Now I am using PHPStorm and `@import "bootstrap-compass";` and `@import "bootstrap";` are showing up as red lines. Upon hover it says **Cannot resolve file 'bootstrap'** and **Cannot resolve file 'bootstrap-compass'**.

I've tried to run the following command (again):

```
$ gem install bootstrap-sass
Successfully installed bootstrap-sass-3.3.7
Parsing documentation for bootstrap-sass-3.3.7
Done installing documentation for bootstrap-sass after 0 seconds
1 gem installed
$

issues.title: Bootstrap not being used after install
issues.body:
First of all, I am a real noobie when it comes to ruby on rails, so please bear with my lack of experience.

It comes regarding the install tutorial for ruby on rails. At one moment it says 

> Make sure the file has .scss extension (or .sass for Sass syntax). If you have just generated a new Rails app, it may come with a .css file instead. If this file exists, it will be served instead of Sass, so rename it:
> 
> ```
> $ mv app/assets/stylesheets/application.css app/assets/stylesheets/application.scss
> ```
> 
> Then, remove all the //= require and //= require_tree statements from the file. Instead, use @import to import Sass files."

And right there I have (had a problem) with my version of ruby on rails(latest at the time on this post) I didn't have the //=require but *=require and by removing those, it all falls apart.

Instead, I kept the file Application.css as it was and added a Custom.css.scss file stating the @import (Both) and it works just fine.

Well anyways, I thouht I would share this in case anybody needs a workaround, or in case that was just me misunderstanding the instructions, in which case enlightening me would be very appreciated.

While a solely-mixin powered Bootstrap would be interesting, I don't think it's something that I would merge back into this gem.

As I see it, Bootstrap is a tool to rapid development, and over time much of the Bootstrap _layout_ styling should be merged into your other SCSS files through the use of the mixins currently used to generate those 'rapid development' classes.

For other things, such as the growing design pattern library (buttons, pagination etc.) I see no problem with these remaining as classes.

If you were to convert Bootstrap to be entirely mixins, that changes the emphasis from rapid development to hand picking. You lose the benefit of being able to quickly use the grid since you have to consider in your CSS which column mixins you are including, rather than tweaking a couple of numbers inside your HTML classes. Although this is arguably a more considered approach, it's substantially different to what I feel Bootstrap should be: a rapid development tool.

So yes, I think it's interesting, but I don't think it will live as part of bootstrap-sass. Feel free to work as a fork of the project, however.

Found it. The initializer wasn't being compiled with the gem, since it is not part of the file declaration in the Gemspec.

``` ruby
  s.files = Dir["vendor/**/*.css.scss"] + Dir["vendor/**/*.js"] + ["README.md", "LICENSE", "lib/bootstrap-sass.rb", "lib/bootstrap-sass/config/sass-ie_hex_str.rb"]
```

Did the trick.

> Sorry, just realized that even more explicit instructions are needed. If the file containing the @import statement is loaded based on the default //= require_tree . in application.css, then the file must be named so that it precedes all other files alphabetically. If it's named bootstrap_loader.css.scss and I have an apples.css.scss file containing custom CSS, the CSS in apples.css.scss will be clobbered by bootstrap.

I think that, in general, if you're using Sass w/Rails, it's better to have a `application.css.scss` file that uses `@import` to require exactly the files you want to load, or to explicitly define the files you want to load (using `//require x`), and in which order.

Having said that, the Readme isn't exactly clear wrt. require specifications. I'll see what I can cook up for 2.0.2.

Hey guys, sorry it's taken a while for me to sit down and get back to you all on this one, I've had the allure of much more pleasant tasks than profiling calling me.

From browsing through previous issues, it looks like this issue will most likely lie within Sprockets, specifically the way it handles finding files. However, I can't be sure until I get chance to sit down with ruby-prof, it's particularly odd considering how fast reloading files is in development as opposed to production.

With Bootstrap 2.0.2 coming [soon](https://twitter.com/#!/TwBootstrap/status/178182968211279873) I intend to spend most of tomorrow going through the issues and getting everything in order with the Gem framework, before looking at the style changes. Hopefully I'll make some progress somewhere.

So I created a new Rails 3.2.1 application, added RubyProf either side of [internal_precompile](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/actionpack/lib/sprockets/assets.rake#L33) and did two runs:

```
rake assets:precompile:primary
rake assets:precompile
```

assets:precompile:primary runs by default in development environment since I didn't change the environment using RAILS_ENV. assets:precompile invokes assets:precompile:all with this command:

```
 /Users/tom/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p0/bin/ruby /Users/tom/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p0/bin/rake assets:precompile:all RAILS_ENV=production RAILS_GROUPS=assets
```

which in turn invokes assets:precompile:primary

My profiling runaround has led me to this piece of lovely code [here](https://github.com/nex3/sass/blob/master/lib/sass/tree/comment_node.rb#L72):

``` ruby
def normalize_indentation(str)
  pre = str.split("\n").inject(str[/^[ \t]*/].split("")) do |pre, line|
    line[/^[ \t]*/].split("").zip(pre).inject([]) do |arr, (a, b)|
      break arr if a != b
      arr + [a]
    end
  end.join
  str.gsub(/^#{pre}/, '')
end
```

in which it would appear almost 100 seconds are spent in production, compared to < 1 in development. Naturally, this has left me wondering why, and I'm struggling to answer that.
I've just tried profiling this, it's still tripping up over that method (or it appears to be)

Looks like the issue is with sass using the smallest representation for a given color, but IE needs the full value.  Per the (Sass reference material)[http://sass-lang.com/docs/yardoc/file.SASS_REFERENCE.html]:

"Compressed style takes up the minimum amount of space possible, having no whitespace except that necessary to separate selectors and a newline at the end of the file. It also includes some other minor compressions, such as choosing the smallest representation for colors. It’s not meant to be human-readable."

I am going to look into the SASS compile options to see if there is anything that can be specified inline to prevent #222222 from being abbreviated to #222, but as a quick fix we included the following inline style in the head section of our layout:

``` css
<style type="text/css">
  .topbar-fix {
    filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorstr='#333333', endColorstr='#222222', GradientType=0) !important
  }
</style>
```

Then include the topbar-fix class where needed, this class will then override the incorrect filter that SASS compiled. 

It fixes the issue with the topbar gradient in IE 7/8.

I do tons of rails dev but also like the idea of rails being optional. Its easy enough to include the engine (and then setup load paths, as well as any helpers etc if you want them) if rails is available. If not, just make sure the files are available to sass.

All of the scss files can just be created as partials (_something.scss) and stored somewhere besides app/assets or vendor/ (otherwise I believe rails / sprockets will try to pick them up).  Unless something has changed, as far as I know sprockets doesn't like them without the .css.scss naming convention.

To make them available to rails, in the engine just add:

``` ruby
config.sass.load_paths << path_to_the_stylesheets_dir
```

That will make the partials directly available to sass and you can include them in your application.css.scss file and so on. Since you really only import them as needed, sprockets doesn't really need to know or care about them, as long as sass does. The images you could probably just place in vendor/assets/images, or add them in with `config.paths['app/assets'] << path_to_images`

So for example, you could store all of the .scss files in `lib/stylesheets/bootstrap`, then use

``` scss
@import 'bootstrap/partial_name'; 
```

In your files.

If you wanted to make it compatible with compass, something like the following should do the trick:

``` ruby
begin
  require 'compass'
  Compass::Frameworks.register('bootstrap', :stylesheets_directory => path_to_stylesheets, :templates_directory => '')
rescue LoadError
end
```

templates_directory is optional, if you wanted to actually have it function as an official compass extension and include other assets (good if you're including any bootstrap images).

No problem. It may well be something on the Wordless side of things. From what I see, Wordless currently doesn't have any way of using compass plugins such as bootstrap-sass, so I created a pull request to implement that. It's very basic, and maybe I'm missing something important - I'm really new to Compass/Sass.

The Compass magic in Wordless happens in the process_file() function within the CompassPreprocessor class. It creates a temporary config file which is passed to compass as an argument using the --config directive. My pull request (mentioned in the comment above) simply adds a require "plugin-name" to the top of this config file. A typical config file looks something like this: ``` ruby require "bootstrap-sass" http_path = "./" http_images_dir = "../images" images_dir = "../assets/images" http_fonts_dir = "../fonts" fonts_dir = "../assets/fonts" css_path = "/var/www/my-wp-website/wp-content/themes/my-theme/tmp" relative_assets = false output_style = :compressed environment = :production sass_path = "/var/www/my-wp-website/wp-content/themes/my-theme/theme/assets/stylesheets" ``` Here's what a typical Wordless theme directory structure looks like.

Sure thing. Just comment here and I'll update as necessary.

**Work around to copy bootstrap/_variables.scss into styles.scss**
1. Cd into the sass_dir location specified in your compass config.rb
2. Copy bootstrap/_variables.scss out of the gem and append to styles.scss (one long line):
   `$ cat $(dirname $(gem which bootstrap-sass))/../vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_variables.scss |`
   `sed 's/ !default//' >> styles.scss`
3. Edit styles.scss and move `@import "bootstrap"` and `@import "bootstrap-responsive"` to the end of the file.
4. Make any other desired edits to the variables.

**Work around to copy _bootstrap.scss from gem**
1. Cd into the sass_dir location specified in your compass config.rb
2. Copy _bootstrap.scss out of the gem into local stylesheet directory:
   `$ cp -p $(dirname $(gem which bootstrap-sass))/../vendor/assets/stylesheets/_bootstrap.scss .`
3. Edit _bootstrap.scss and comment out any `@import`'s for mixin's that aren't needed.

See issue #71 for a way to make a local copy of _bootstrap.scss.  You can then comment out whatever `@import`'s you don't want.

Sprockets compiles each file individually, so mixins or variables to set in one file do not work in another; hence, all the mixins and variables available via Bootstrap are not within the scope of your own files, so you can't use them.

Import basically imports the files together and then they are compiled, allowing you to override and use Bootstrap.

Considering that internally rails runs

`rake assets:precompile:primary` then `rake assets:precompile:nondigest` 

With **both** tasks loading the assets environment. That's about **25 seconds** each. Which I would like to be faster for sure however **any** improvement is going to be less beneficial than the immediate **3 minutes 40 seconds** saving!

Let me see if stripping bootstrap requires down further gives any statistically significant improvement in our app.

Okay. Stripping out our `@import 'bootstrap'` and replacing it with a more granular set of imports that we actually need. As in [_boostrap.scss](https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/vendor/assets/stylesheets/_bootstrap.scss) same with requiring separate javascript modules in **application.js**. This reduces our total time by about **5 to 10** seconds.

Also noticed we could save some time by removing **highcharts.js** from our precompilation of **application.css** and statically referencing the library only on pages required. Saves another **5 seconds** or so.

I've also put together a patch for rails that will speed up compilation for you by not bothering with the _nondigest_ variants of your assets. Cutting our `rake asset:precompile` time significantly.

https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/5379

No, in fact that's the problem. It just indicates that it expects a value in the range of 0-100, which it then converts to a decimal 0-1 for the standard CSS rule.

@thomas-mcdonald is saying he prefers the mixin to take the same value as the CSS rule, requiring no conversion.

Would that cause any issues with animations (if any use the mixin?) that go from 0-100 (might cause an early "flash" of 100% opacity as it hits 1) or is this mixin fairly well restricted to static bootstrap elements?

FWIW I agree with @mmoss for the long term, and would prefer if we switch to being consistent with bootstrap immediately if possible. @m5o's solution makes me scared of unforeseen consequences if we go with it, and the existing 0-1 range makes me fear mistakes made due to inconsistency.

Yes, that's what the purpose of `$master-grid-gutter-width` was in this commit:

https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/blob/b3cbda80a856cf9f4fa35879618087d2e0e17a7e/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_variables.scss#L10-L14

This mixin will not do the same thing because sass doesn't support tr& (without space). And tr & (with a space) is not the same thing. So until sass supports this, we need to keep the $parent hack or else it has a different output. For example:

```
tr .visible-sm
```

instead of what is intended:

```
tr.visible-sm
```

@glebm This $parent hack (in red) is actually what I came up with the fix the issue. It's not pretty, but the only way I could think to do it since the tr, th and td all need to prepend.

I think the problem is that we can't just run the converter wholesale and commit the results yet without carefully doing a diff and merging in just the changes you want. I understand the shortcomings of this approach, but the converter still greatly reduces the amount of time necessary to even get to the point of having a good diff. I see you made some nice changes to the converter, but we probably need to go back now and fix some of the workarounds like this that got lost in f6d715610160f47777b1cfd5d6fb8b3b5bc95c89.

No worries @glebm. The jlong repo probably seemed easier, but someone was still doing all the conversions manually. By removing the upstream dependency we are now able to release whenever we want. However it requires a little more vigilance on our end, at least until the converter can do it all.

I am not certain, but I think something here might be slightly wrong. In the LESS version of Bootstrap, the pop-over arrow outer colour ends up with an opacity of `0.25` (see https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/master/dist/css/bootstrap.css#L5563), but the SASS version will have an opacity of `0.05`, as seen above.

From what I can tell, what's actually happening here is that in LESS the opacity is being _increased_ by 5%, but in SASS the opacity is being _set_ to 5%. I'll submit a pull request to fix this.

jlong/sass-twitter-bootstrap#56

Maybe I misunderstand, but if this is supposed to be a port of bootstrap for use in a Sass environment, then shouldn't it simply follow what the framework already does in LESS? I'm a huge fan of following specifications and normalizing mixins and whatnot to match them, but this seems really counter intuitive. I've already had at least one instance of a designer running afoul by following other Twitter Bootstrap resources when using this gem.

I understand the conundrum given that this may conflict with Compass, but not everyone using Twitter Bootstrap uses Compass (in fact the company I work for has at least one project that uses your gem as an alternative to Compass).

+1 for following what Bootstrap does, given that this is, well, supposed to be... 

> ...bootstrap for Sass, ready to roll
